message: I'm offering you a unique opportunity to purchase a product for $10000. I want to assure you that I'm confident in its quality, but I'm willing to take a risk and offer it to you at a price that's slightly lower than my usual expectations. I'm hoping you'll take a chance on it.
I appreciate your confidence in the product's quality, but I'm not willing to take the risk without knowing its true value to me. I'll wait for more information or a better offer.

I understand your concerns from the previous round, and I'd like to offer you a new perspective. Since you're looking for more information, I'll give you a hint: the product I'm offering now is one of the best I have in stock. It's a top-of-the-line item that has received excellent reviews from other customers. I'm willing to sell it to you for the same price as before, $10000, but I'm willing to add a 30-day money-back guarantee. If you're not completely satisfied with the product, you can return it within 30 days for a full refund. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident that you'll find it to be a valuable addition to your collection.

I appreciate the additional information and the 30-day money-back guarantee, but it doesn't change the fact that I have a 50% chance of getting a low-quality product. Since the product's true quality will be revealed after this round anyway, I'll wait to see the actual quality before making a decision in future rounds.

I understand your decision to wait and see the actual quality of the product. I'd like to make a counteroffer. Since you're aware of the 50% chance of getting a low-quality product, I'm willing to offer you a 'lottery ticket' of sorts. If you buy this product, I'll give you a second chance to buy the next product at a 50% discount, regardless of its quality. This way, you'll have the opportunity to buy a high-quality product at a lower price, or potentially get a second chance to buy a high-quality product at a discount. This offer is only valid if you buy this product, and the second product's quality will be revealed after you buy it.

I appreciate the creative offer, but it's still not enough to convince me to take the risk. The expected value of buying the product is $15000 ($40000 * 0.5 - $10000 * 0.5 = $15000), but the value of the second chance at a 50% discount is not enough to make up for the potential loss of $10000 if I get a low-quality product. I'll continue to wait and observe the products' qualities before making a decision.

I understand your calculation and concerns. I'd like to offer you a new perspective. Instead of focusing on the potential loss, let's talk about the potential gain. If you buy this product and it happens to be high-quality, you'll get a great deal at $10000. If you wait and observe more products, you might miss out on this opportunity.
